title: How and when to cut back cast iron plants in South Louisiana
content: Question for Dan Gill: I've heard you mention that I can totally cut back my cast iron plants and they will just put out new growth. Is there a time of year that is best to do this? How long will it take for them to regrow again? --Jeni Ducoing Answer: Yes, this can be done. It is best done in the spring, around February or March, before the new spring growth. You may, however, cut them back now and they will still grow back out. When cast iron plants are cut back to the ground, they will grow back out shorter and thinner. It will take them until next summer to get back to the thickness and height they were before you cut them back. If there are not too many unattractive leaves and lots of healthy leaves, it is best to just individually prune out the unattractive leaves. Dan Gill is a horticulturist with the LSU AgCenter. Email questions to dgill@agcenter.lsu.edu or add them to the comment section below. Follow his stories at www.nola.com/homegarden, on Facebook and @nolahomegarden on Instagram.
contentWithMarkup: If you cut them back, they will put out new growth. Here's how to revive these shade-loving plants.

author.name: Dan Gill, The Times-Picayune garden columnist
